webTitle: BT tops 1 million TV customers mark

fields.bodyText: BT's £2bn bet on sports broadcasting has lifted annual revenues at its consumer division for the first time in a decade, with a 4% increase to just over £4bn, as it took the lion's share of new broadband subscribers. The launch of two live sports channels, broadcast from the former Olympic park in Stratford last summer, improved the brand, according to Gavin Patterson, the chief executive, who masterminded the push into football in his previous role as boss of the group's retail arm. "There has been more of a buzz around BT, which opens us up to a wider group of customers," he said. A television offering boosted by Premier League and Champions League football helped BT secure 170,000 net new broadband subscribers in the most recent quarter – subscribers get the sports channels free. This was a 79% share of all new broadband homes on the BT network, which is also used by other operators including Sky and TalkTalk, and it beat Sky's 70,000 net new subscribers in the same period. Virgin broadband is on a separate network. BT now has 1 million paying television customers, according to its full-year results on Thursday, adding 46,000 in the quarter, thanks to the demand for Premier League football. But the total number of homes watching its sports channels is 5m if those getting the service via Sky and Virgin Media set-top boxes are included. Patterson played down expectations that BT is planning to snatch the lion's share of Premier League rights from Sky when the auction for the next three-year deal begins later this year, saying his options remained open. Having already secured the next Champions League, BT will have 350 live games a season from 2015. "Come next Premier League auction, we've got more choice in terms of our strategy," he said. "If we don't decide to increase the number of games we go for, we've still got a very strong schedule based around Europe." The telecoms group beat forecasts to report overall revenues flat on last year at £18.3bn, and announced a 15% dividend increase with more over the next two years. BT shares rose nearly 3% to 388p. But television signings have slowed, from a peak of 70,000 in September, just after the launch of BT Sport. The company has insisted its investment in football was all about stopping the slow bleed of phone and broadband customers to Sky and other operators. Since the launch of BT Sport last summer, its share of all new broadband signings is now typically higher than 75%, compared with 50% before. It also said it had completed its project to extend superfast fibre-optic cables to street cabinets serving two-thirds of the UK, 21 months ahead of schedule. BT's network now passes 19m premises, and work has started on all 44 local authority contracts to build a publicly funded rural network that will extend fibre to more than 90% of the country. BT said some 630,000 homes had now been connected under the Broadband Delivery UK scheme. Communications minister Ed Vaizey said: "The UK now has the widest fibre availability of the top five European economies as well as the highest takeup rate. Commercial operators like BT, with support from government, are delivering one of the fastest rollouts of fibre in the world and these figures demonstrate that the government's aim to provide access to superfast speeds to 95% of the UK by 2017 is well on track." Demand for superfast fibre-optic broadband is running at an all-time high, with a new customer connected to BT's network every 20 seconds. Over the past quarter, 347,000 were plugged in, and there are now 2.7 million, with 2.1 million buying the service from the company itself and the rest from operators such as Sky and TalkTalk. "Fibre broadband is the future and BT has invested billions of pounds to ensure as many people as possible can benefit," said Patterson. "The early achievement of this milestone marks the culmination of several years of hard work by our engineers and planners." Overall profit at the group was ahead of expectations, with adjusted profit before tax 9% higher at £901m for the quarter. Patterson said revenues would be flat during the coming financial year, but would grow in the year ending March 2016. He increased the full-year dividend by 15% to 10.9p, with a final dividend 15% higher at 7.5p. BT expects to increase its dividend by between 10% and 15% for each of the next two years.

webTitle: Sage chief executive retires after 17 years

fields.standfirst: Guy Berruyer says there are still 'has many things I want to achieve besides my executive career'
fields.body:
Sage Group, the Newcastle-based FTSE 100 software firm, surprised investors by announcing that chief executive Guy Berruyer is to retire after 17 years with the company.

The shares fell 5.5% to 399p as the accounting software specialist said he was leaving for lifestyle reasons and would be gone by the end of March 2015.

"Life is about making choices, and at 63 years old I still have many things I want to achieve besides my executive career," said Berruyer.

Sage is making a difficult transition from selling software installed on computers to providing cloud based services that can be accessed from the office or on the go, and are paid for by subscription rather than one-off licence fees.

Berruyer took the helm in October 2010, succeeding Paul Walker, who had led Sage since 1994 and overseen its growth into one of Britain's largest software companies.

Analysts expressed surprised that Berruyer was stepping down before October 2015, the deadline for three-year growth targets he set for the company. David Tomas at broker Numis wrote: "With Guy having set his target at 6% growth for 2015, to retire 'by March 2015' means he will not be around to see his strategy through. After 17 years with Sage, it seems surprising that he does not want to hang on for the last few months to see if he delivers."

The news came as Sage reported half-year results in line with expectations, with underlying earnings of £180m just below City forecasts, and organic growth of 5%.

Headhunters will begin the search for a replacement, with broker Panmure Gordon tipping Pascal Houillon, head of Sage's US operations, as the most promising internal candidate, saying the American arm had moved more quickly towards a cloud-based model.

Sage chairman Donal Brydon said: "The Board understands the reasons that have led Guy to his decision and thanks him for his service to Sage. During his four years as chief executive Guy has set the company on a new path to growth, clarified the strategy and ensured performance against publicly communicated objectives. He will leave Sage in good shape for his successor with a strong team in place."

webTitle: Godzilla and X-Men to boost Cineworld despite World Cup distraction

fields.standfirst: Cinema group says it expects to meet market expectations for full year results
fields.body:
The World Cup excuses are beginning to arrive ahead of the tournament starting in June.

On Wednesday credit specialist Experian said the competition was likely to hit its business in Brazil - the host country - and now Cineworld has warned film attendance is likely to be lower during the course of the event.

This, however, is hardly a revelation and after an early dip, the cinema group's shares are now unchanged at 342.5p.

Reporting a 33.8% rise in revenues for the 18 weeks to the start of May, the company said it was confident of meeting market expectations for the year. Ahead of the World Cup, it said there were a number of major films likely to boost the box office:

There is a strong line-up of films for the remainder of the first half, including Godzilla, X-Men: Days of Future Past and Maleficent, which are expected to be popular across all territories.

Analysts remained positive on the business. Douglas Jack at Numis said:

Last week, we said Cineworld's share price offered a buying opportunity, but in light of today's statement, that claim was not strong enough. During the first 18 weeks, Cineworld's box office outperformed a flat UK market by 7% and the company is generating double-digit like for like admission growth in Europe. With strong like for like trading prospects ahead over the next 20 months, we would still buy the shares and are raising our target price to 420p from 380p.

Nick Batram at Peel Hunt said:

The recent recovery in the share price should receive a further boost from the strength of the statement. It is too soon to upgrade and the impact of the World Cup is uncertain at this stage. Nevertheless, the performance is ahead of where we expected it to be.

webTitle: Sage leads FTSE 100 fallers as chief executive Berruyer announces retirement

fields.standfirst: Software group says on track to meet targets but departure news hits share price
fields.body:
Sage is the biggest faller in the FTSE 100 despite in-line figures, as the accounting software specialist announce the retirement of its chief executive.

Guy Berruyer will step down sometime in the next eleven months, the company said, as it reported a 4.9% rise in first half revenues to £657m (before the negative effect of exchange rates) and said it was confident for the rest of the year. It said it was on course to hit its target of 6% organic growth for 2015.

But its shares have dropped 22p or 5% to 400p, and analyst Julian Yates at Investec repeated his sell recommendation, saying Berruyer's proposed departure was unexpected:

First half results were broadly in line, with EBITA of £180m versus our £185.9m (consensus £184.3m). Organic growth was 5%, a good result, driven by recurring sales, with software sales flat due to continued EMEA [Europe, Middle East and Africa] weakness. The main news is that Guy Berruyer is retiring and will leave the business before the end of his three year target timeline of 2015.
Sage is making good progress against its goals, but with the comparatives becoming more challenging, we still remain cautious about the group hitting its 6% organic growth target, while necessary investment in the business is likely to cramp margin expansion in our view. There was no commentary on the group's 1% margin improvement target. The news of the chief executive's retirement is also likely to surprise and may raise questions over the 2015 targets, as these were financial goals closely associated with him. We continue to see the stock as fully valued and retain our PE based target price [of 320p] and sell recommendation.

Over at Panmure Gordon George O'Connor kept his hold recommendation, and seemed less surprised about Berruyer's departure:

The interim results are in line – in truth a smidgen better at revenue due to Europe doing well. We make minor changes to 2014 estimates taking earnings per share from 23.64p to 23.7p and increasing dividends per share from 12.11p to 12.2p. We note goodish traction in Cloud and SageOne but weaker in SagePay (down 10% year on year) and X3 (the flagship top end product).
The big news is that Guy Berruyer has announced his intention to retire. He is 63 years old so we had expected it. Our view is that head of US Pascal Houillon is the best-placed internal candidate – given that the US has moved to the newer operating model faster than the other regions. However, we are mindful that shareholders might be minded to look for an external candidate to drive stronger growth and create a more modern product offer. Given the full valuation, we retain our hold but increase our target price to 400p from 373p.

webTitle: SuperGroup slides 14% after Easter and eBay hit sales

fields.standfirst: Fashion retailer says full year profits will be at the lower end of City expectations
fields.body:
With markets recovering after two days of dips, a 14% slump in the shares of SuperGroup stands out even more.

The fashion retailer behind the Superdry brand warned full year profits would be at the lower end of City forecasts of £61m to £65m after fourth quarter like for like sales fell 3.1%. It blamed the late timing of Easter and a planned reduction in lower margin sales through eBay. The shares, which fell 20% in April, are currently down 191p to £11.57. Analyst Nick Bubb said:

The SuperGroup share price has been notably weak recently, as if something was amiss in current trading, and today's pre-close update indeed confirms that retail trading has been disappointing, with like for like sales slightly down in the fourth quarter, by 3.1% or by 1.3% adjusted for the reduced eBay sales.
Despite strong wholesale orders and a smooth transition to the new warehouse, SuperGroup has warned that full-year profits will be at the lower end of the...range. On the conference call with analysts at 8am, finance director Shaun Wills pointed to the impact on retail of the late and weak Easter trading period, the strong sales of outerwear in the fourth quarter last year because of the cold spring weather and the increased promotional activity in the young fashion market pre-Easter. But the City is nervous about the history of SuperGroup profit warnings and the shares are down... in early trading.

Freddie George at Cantor Fitzgerald kept his buy rating but said:

No explanation for the decline in volumes other than there is mention of a challenging trading environment. We suspect that the company has had a disappointing April and there has been weaker momentum in womenswear against difficult comparatives last year.
Following this update, we are marginally revising down our 2014 pre-tax profits forecasts of £62.5m to £61.5m taking earnings per share down from 57.0p to 56.1p but still representing growth of 17% on the previous year. For the time being, in view of the operational gearing, arising from the infrastructure investment, we are retaining our 2015 forecast of £70.0m (earnings per share of 63.6p). We reiterate our buy recommendation but are reducing our target price to 1,500p from 1,650p. There has now been significant investment in infrastructure and management. There also continues to be a great opportunity to drive international sales boosted by the announcement of several recent deals, including the acquisition of its German agency business for £3.5m and the link-ups in Turkey and SE Asia. The next step may be the acquisition of the US license. In addition, the company will continue to drive on-line sales.

On a busy day for corporate news, and ahead of meetings of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee and the European Central Bank, the FTSE 100 is up 31.13 points at 6765.31. Better than expected Chinese trade data and Wednesday's more conciliatory tone from Russia's Vladimir Putin over Ukraine has soothed some of investors' recent nerves.

There is a definite split between the good and the bad as far as the share price reaction to the various company updates is concern.

Moving higher are Barclays, up 13.25p to 256.55p in the wake of its strategic plans which include 19,000 job losses, and BT, 9.4p better at 386.2p after in line profits unchanged at £6.1bn despite hefty investment in its sports operations.

Prudential has climbed 33p to 1410.5p following news of 29% growth in first quarter new business, while Barratt Developments is up 8.2p at 384.5p after announcing a 47% rise in forward sales.

But the dismal times at Morrisons continue, with its shares 3p lower at 187.8p after a 7.1% fall in underlying first quarter sales.

British Gas owner Centrica is also under pressure, down 7.2p at 319.6p as it warned of a reduced outlook for earnings in 2014.

Meanwhile AstraZeneca has added 85.5p to 4716.5p on talk of a higher bid of around £53 a share from predator Pfizer.

It blamed the late timing of Easter and a planned reduction in lower margin sales through eBay. The shares, which fell 20% in April, are currently down 191p to £11.57. Analyst Nick Bubb said: The SuperGroup share price has been notably weak recently, as if something was amiss in current trading, and today's pre-close update indeed confirms that retail trading has been disappointing, with like for like sales slightly down in the fourth quarter, by 3.1% or by 1.3% adjusted for the reduced eBay sales. Despite strong wholesale orders and a smooth transition to the new warehouse, SuperGroup has warned that full-year profits will be at the lower end of the...range. On the conference call with analysts at 8am, finance director Shaun Wills pointed to the impact on retail of the late and weak Easter trading period, the strong sales of outerwear in the fourth quarter last year because of the cold spring weather and the increased promotional activity in the young fashion market pre-Easter. But the City is nervous about the history of SuperGroup profit warnings and the shares are down... in early trading. Freddie George at Cantor Fitzgerald kept his buy rating but said: No explanation for the decline in volumes other than there is mention of a challenging trading environment. We suspect that the company has had a disappointing April and there has been weaker momentum in womenswear against difficult comparatives last year. Following this update, we are marginally revising down our 2014 pre-tax profits forecasts of £62.5m to £61.5m taking earnings per share down from 57.0p to 56.1p but still representing growth of 17% on the previous year. For the time being, in view of the operational gearing, arising from the infrastructure investment, we are retaining our 2015 forecast of £70.0m (earnings per share of 63.6p). We reiterate our buy recommendation but are reducing our target price to 1,500p from 1,650p. There has now been significant investment in infrastructure and management. There also continues to be a great opportunity to drive international sales boosted by the announcement of several recent deals, including the acquisition of its German agency business for £3.5m and the link-ups in Turkey and SE Asia. The next step may be the acquisition of the US license. In addition, the company will continue to drive on-line sales. On a busy day for corporate news, and ahead of meetings of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee and the European Central Bank, the FTSE 100 is up 31.13 points at 6765.31. Better than expected Chinese trade data and Wednesday's more conciliatory tone from Russia's Vladimir Putin over Ukraine has soothed some of investors' recent nerves. There is a definite split between the good and the bad as far as the share price reaction to the various company updates is concern. Moving higher are Barclays, up 13.25p to 256.55p in the wake of its strategic plans which include 19,000 job losses, and BT, 9.4p better at 386.2p after in line profits unchanged at £6.1bn despite hefty investment in its sports operations. webTitle: Morrisons' sales slump by more than 7%

fields.standfirst: Supermarket's boss says price cuts will attract customers after worst-than-expected fall in like-for-like sales in quarter to 4 May
fields.body:
Morrisons has reported a 7.1% slump in sales in the past three months, but its chief executive claimed the turnaround strategy was on track as a new price cutting campaign started.

Dalton Philips said he was confident that the "I'm cheaper" price cuts, which permanently lowered prices by an average of 17% on 1,200 products a week ago, will draw in customers. The struggling supermarket chain, which bills itself as a value-led grocer with a focus on fresh food, even projected the image of a giant baguette on to the Angel of the North in Gateshead as part of its campaign.

Total sales excluding fuel fell 4.2% in the 13 weeks to 4 May, while like-for-like sales tumbled 7.1%. This was a bigger fall than analysts had expected and compares with a decline of 5.6% over Christmas and a 2.8% drop last year.

The company said its big cost savings programme was on track and did not change its £325m to £375m profit guidance for 2014. Philips set out plans in March to save £1bn over the next three years. Morrisons has been changing the layout of its stores, has invested in IT and has opened 11 local convenience stores during the quarter – with a target to have up to 200 open by the end of the year.

The independent retail analyst Nick Bubb described the sales figures as "dreadful". He said: "Price deflation will make the sales figures worse not better in the short run, before sales volumes pick up. Fortunately, the big cost savings programme is on track.

"Management will be under pressure to explain the thinking behind the new 'I'm cheaper' price campaign, given the scepticism expressed by Sainsbury's yesterday on how real their price cuts are."

The outgoing Sainsbury's boss, Justin King, dismissed the £300m of price cuts announced by Morrisons as a "skirmish". The industry data from Kantar Worldpanel on Wednesday showed that Morrisons, Tesco and Sainsbury's had all lost market share in the past three months. The UK grocery market as a whole grew by 1.9%, the lowest growth for at least 11 years.

Morrisons' new website Morrisons.com has launched in Warwickshire and Yorkshire, and next Monday the company will make its first deliveries in London. The aim is to reach up to half of UK households by the end of 2014 and Morrisons hopes to make more than £500m of annual sales from online and convenience stores.

Philips said: "The reaction of our customers to the 1,200 'I'm cheaper' price cuts we announced last week has been very positive. Although it will take time for their full impact to be felt, we are confident that these meaningful and permanent reductions in our prices will enable our clear points of difference to resonate strongly with consumers."

webTitle: James Packer v David Gyngell: News Corp watermark hindered police

fields.standfirst: Investigation into Bondi street brawl stalled because photographic branding made early evidence ‘difficult to see’
fields.body:
News Corp’s overly enthusiastic protection of photographs of James Packer and David Gyngell hindered a police investigation into their fight in Bondi because the watermark covered up what was going on.

NSW acting assistant police commissioner Mark Walton said at a press conference on Wednesday that police had officially begun inquiries into the incident in which two of Australia’s most powerful men fought in the street.

Billionaire Packer, and Gyngell, the head of the Nine Network, came to blows on Sunday, reportedly over a misunderstanding about a Nine camera truck which Packer believed was camped out to catch the arrival of his rumoured partner, supermodel Miranda Kerr.

News Corp reportedly bought photographs of the fight for more than $200,000 on Monday, publishing them online behind heavy watermarks before plastering various snapshots across the nation’s front pages the following day.

The watermarked images were quickly ridiculed – including by some News Corp publications.

"The early material was so difficult to see what was going on because of the branding of it," Walton told media on Wednesday.

"I certainly wasn't expecting the police to rush out there."

A spokesman for NSW police told Guardian Australia Walton was not joking. The watermarks “genuinely made it very hard to see through what was going on in the background”, he said.

The spokesman could not confirm whether police had earlier requested unmarked copies of the photographs from News Corp.

The police investigation – which was launched despite no complaint filed by either Packer or Gyngell – will determine whether the fight amounted to assault or affray.

Walton acknowledged police were slow to begin an investigation, but said they had now made contact with legal representatives of both Packer and Gyngell requesting an interview with the pair.

“We have had contact through a legal adviser indicating if they wish to indicate anything to us, come and see us, they're welcome to do so," he said.

"There's no compulsion for anyone to be interviewed in these circumstances."

A lack of police action in the days immediately following the incident attracted some criticism that Packer and Gyngell appeared to be escaping consequences at a time when government and law enforcement are focusing so heavily on violence in Sydney.

Walton said the profiles of the two men had “no relevance to the determination in this matter”.

The photographer responsible for the Packer-Gyngell images, Brendan Beirne, told AAP he had complied with a police request to hand over more than 300 pictures of the brawl during a two-hour witness interview on Wednesday.

webTitle: Family tax benefit cuts will hurt the average family more than a levy

fields.standfirst: For real middle-income earners, changes to family assistance will be where the real budget pain lies
fields.body:
In the past week the government has copped a lot of heat for proposing to introduce a deficit levy on people earning $80,000 and above. The opposition leader, Bill Shorten, for example, suggested it was “slugging ordinary Australians”. But in reality “ordinary Australians” would have to worry about the deficit levy only if they were about to get a 60% raise in their income. For real middle-income earners, the changes to the family tax benefit will be where the real budget pain lies.

There have been a few tears shed lately in the right-wing media for high-income earners being asked to shoulder a greater burden of tax. And certainly in our progressive taxation system higher-income earners do pay more tax.

Last week the ATO released its latest taxation statistics for 2011-12. In that year the top 1% earned 9% of all taxable income and paid 16.4% of all income tax:

The average tax rate paid by those in the top 1% was 41%. This sounds high, but back in 2002-03 it was 43.4% and even in 2007-08, after the Howard government tax cuts, it was still 42%.

And while 16.4% of tax paid by just 1% of all taxpayers also sounds a lot, it’s actually less than it has been for a while:

The richest are not doing it any tougher now than they have before.

But as F. Scott Fitzgerald noted, the rich are different from you and me.

When we are talking the top 1% we are talking people whose taxable income in 2011-12 was above $291,000. And while that is high, the average taxable income of the top 1% was a rather more sizeable $588,893.

The discussion of the deficit levy, however, has varied across the past week from it kicking in at the second highest tax-rate threshold of $80,000 to the recent reports it will begin at $150,000.

Are any of these “average Australians”?

This is where is gets confusing and also allows for a bit of trickiness.

Take for example the Institute of Public Affairs, which issued a media release decrying the deficit levy, stating, “Someone earning $80,000 a year is well off, but they’re not rich. Teachers and nurses can earn well in excess of $80,000 per annum.”

The problem with this is that “rich” and “well off” are subjective terms. So let’s put some figures into the equation.

The average full-time annual earnings is $75,000, which suggests $80,000 is not that far above it. But of course not everyone works full-time (and the amount is also different for women – average full-time earnings for women is about $67,000). The average total earnings, which cover all employees, is about $58,000.

So that’s a fair drop.

But “average” is misleading, because it is skewed by higher incomes. If you have five people earning $20,000, $30,000, $40,000, $50,000 and $130,000, then the average is $54,000, but only one person in the group earns that amount.

When we most often talk of “average” (or Shorten’s “ordinary”) Australians, we’re actually more likely to be thinking “median” – ie middle income, the point where half of the people earn more and half earn less.

And in 2011-12, the median taxable income was not $75,000, nor $58,000, but just $49,600. Which means that someone on $80,000 is 60% above the median income.

Earning $80,000 puts you in the top 20% of all income earners, $100,000 gets you into the top 12%, $150,000 into the top 5% and $180,000 has you in the top 3%. And yes, the wealthy pay most of the tax. The top 20%, for example, pay about 61% of all tax, but they also earn about 45% of all income:

Interestingly, our view of “well-off” would not have changed due to the changes to 2nd highest tax bracket changes. The ratio of that threshold to the median taxable income has stayed pretty constant since 2002. The top tax threshold, however, has zoomed away from the median income:

In 2003-04 the top tax threshold was only 1.8 times the median taxable income. If we had the same ratio now, the top tax threshold would kick in at $99,000 – if being “rich” is to be part of the top tax bracket, then you need a lot more money to be rich than you used to.

But it is worth remembering median income changes according to your family situation.

The median income for a family of four is not the same as for a single person. Clearly it costs more to feed and house four people than one. The ABS takes this into account when it works out the “equivalised household income”. Its latest data for 2011-12 projected that the median income for a single person after tax had been paid and benefits received was $41,080. But for a family of four (two adults and two kids) the median household income would be $86,000.

Now if that household had only one earner then she or he would individually be in the top 20% of incomes, but his/her whole household would be smack bang in middle Australia.

That is why family tax benefit parts A and B exist, even for families whose household taxable income is more than $100,000, and why “middle-class” welfare is perhaps more accurate than its deriders suggest. It’s also why changes to the family tax benefit which may affect households earning more than $100,000 will be much more likely to hit “ordinary Australians” than will a deficit levy for those earning $80,000, let alone anyone on $150,000.

And even more crucially, the prime minister, Tony Abbott, is promising the deficit levy will be temporary. The cuts to family assistance, however, will permanent. If Shorten was really worried about ordinary Australians, family tax benefit is where he should focus his attack.
